import numpy as np
import pandas as pd

train = pd.read_csv("../input/train.csv")
test = pd.read_csv("../input/test.csv")
sample_submission = pd.read_csv("../input/sample_submission.csv")

source.5fa5787a:
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

fig = plt.figure(figsize=(20,3))

for i in range(5):
    ax = fig.add_subplot(1,5,i+1)
    train["{}".format(i)].hist(bins=25,ax=ax)
    ax.set_title("feature {}".format(i))

plt.tight_layout()
plt.show()

corrs = train.corr().abs().unstack().sort_values().reset_index()
corrs = corrs[corrs["level_0"] != corrs["level_1"]]
corrs = corrs.loc[corrs.index % 2 == 1].reset_index(drop=True)
source.c9c2c156:
fig = plt.figure(figsize=(8,8))
ax = fig.add_subplot(111)

ax.matshow(train.drop("id",axis=1).corr())
ax.set_xticklabels(train.columns)
ax.set_yticklabels(train.columns)

plt.show()

source.6de3c4e6:
We can see that the correlations between features are lower than 0.081, and the correlations between a feature and the target is at most 0.37. We don't have any highly correlated features, and we don't have features that are completely uncorrelated with the target.

Here's a (crappy) chart showing the correlations.
